description: From the trademark Klaxon, based on Ancient Greek κλάζω (klázō, “make a sharp sound; scream”) (from Proto-Indo-European *glag- (“to make a noise, clap, twitter”), from *gal- (“to roop, scream, shout”)). The word was coined by Franklyn Hallett Lovell Jr., the founder of the Lovell-McConnell Manufacturing Co. of Newark, New Jersey, USA, which in 1908 obtained a licence of the patent to the machine generating the sound from American inventor Miller Reese Hutchison (1876–1944).

entries.meaning: A loud electric alarm or horn. [from 1908]

verbs.description: klaxon (third-person singular simple present klaxons, present participle klaxoning, simple past and past participle klaxoned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To produce a loud, siren-like wail.
